address.streetAddress: 470 Queens Quay W Walter Carsen Centre

description: One of the top international ballet companies, The National Ballet of Canada was founded in 1951 by Celia Franca. A company of 70 dancers with its own orchestra, the National Ballet has been led by Artistic Director Karen Kain, one of the greatest ballerinas of her generation, since 2005. Renowned for its diverse repertoire, the company performs traditional full-length classics, embraces contemporary work and encourages the creation of new ballets as well as the development of Canadian choreographers.

reviews.title: Have a ball!
text: I was looking for something my partner and I could do over the holiday break that was fun and shake off the rust a little bit when I found this class! I swear my phone is listening to me sometimes because things like these always seem to pop up online right after I finish talking about them. The class was so worth it though, and Marion is the sweetest instructor ever. My partner and I had no dance experience before and she taught us all we needed to know. If you do sign up for Marion’s class, make sure you have a good partner. The tango is meant to be a two-person dance, and if your partner isn’t engaged, like mine wasn’t unfortunately, then it will be hard when you do your final performance. I can’t recommend this class enough though.

reviews.title: Prokofiev rules!
text: We're often in the Four Seasons to attend COC performances, but this is the first ballet I've been to in years. Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet is not to be missde however: the music is spectacular. The ballet is also very good. An enjoyable evening!

reviews.title: Beautiful Facilitiesand Great Teachers.
text: As an avid amateur dancer it was truly a privilege and honour to attend classes here.  The studios are huge and well lit.   The are photos of great dancers past and present everywhere.   It's like walking into a great cathedral of Canadian Dance :)

reviews.title: Stupendious Swan Lake
text: Finally after waiting since 2020 we were able to see Swan Lake in June! It was well worth the wait. I had seen Swan Lake many times while growing up-of course watching Karen Kain and I was able to obtain her autograph. Well sadly no Karen Kain to meet after the show this time, my wonderful husband and I were able to enjoy a wonderful performance. The costumes and scenery moved in ways that enhanced the movement of the dancers. Overall a beautiful experience. We will be back indeed.

You may want to have a better dress code for evening performances. While people were dressed all very differently from a tux to torn shorts and flip flops there is something to be said to dress up for the artists and have a  nighty on the town. This would also likely end the many arguments we heard young couples having where one partner felt the other was undressed. You are not likely to lose patrons if you enforce/encourage a code. :)

reviews.title: Deeply disturbing
text: I have attended the ballet regularly for many years and been an annual supporter as well. I am so saddened to see that I will no longer feel welcome again. When an establishment chooses to exclude people from participating in their service just because they can I think it is discriminatory.  When there is no scientific evidence to support the notion that one group of people pose a greater risk to others, than any other group and in fact that notion is irrational, the voluntary choice to refuse entry is discriminatory.  You may not feel it is significant because fear mongering has influenced your view along the way.  But anyone who lives discrimination knows how strong the power to persuade is and how willing those who want to protect their own privilege are to exclude anyone who challenges it it any way. I am truly disappointed that many artistic establishments have chosen to discriminate.  It has to be wrong no matter how much it feels justified.   If we haven’t learned that yet then what needs to happen before we do?

reviews.title: The Nutcracker - absolutely amazing ballet
text: My partner and I saw The Nutcracker performance at the Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts on December 24th, 2019. It was the third time I saw this performance. And I liked it very much again.

The James Kudelka's version is absolutely different than versions, you can see in Europe. The story is set in 19th century Russia. The first act is so nice! Showing a celebration of Christmas in a large village barn was a wonderful idea. (Normally this act takes place in a big room with a Christmas tree.)

I liked the dance of Bears and the Horse, cannon firing confetti into the audience - another lovely idea. The Sugar Plum Fairy appeared on the stage in a huge golden Fabergé egg, the Snow Queen danced not only with Snow Flakes but with two men - Icicles, dance of the Waiters was simply amazing! Flower Waltz showes a Bee flying in the meadow from flower to flower.

I really loved all the costumes. Santo Loquasto did a great job on them. Dancers were great, Koto Ishihara as the Sugar Plum Fairy (it was her debut that day) was so beautiful and I really appreciated her ballet technique.

I would like to mention the orchestra - the musicians played very well, the sound of the music was clear and nice. I found very lovely and funny the gesture of the conductor, when he put during final curtain call a red nose on his nose.
This the Nutcracker version is very unique and absolutely amazing. I would like to see it again and again when I'm back in Toronto during Christmas holidays.

reviews.title: Unique version of Nutcracker
text: My partner & I attended a matinee performance of the Nutcracker at the Four Seasons Centre for the Performing arts on a recent afternoon. The NBOC’s version is not the traditional one that you can see most every company perform but rather a more ethereal and dreamy version. My favourite parts are the opening with the set of a barn rather than in a house and the faberge egg in the second act where the sugar plum fairy emerges for her dance. The theatre is nice and comfortable with ample legroom even for a tall guy like me. Well worth a stop while in Toronto.

reviews.title: What an enriching experience
text: This was our fourth visit to experience the National Ballet of Canada's Nutcracker ballet (the first at the former O'Keefe Theatre, 3 in the Four Seasons Centre). Box seats are a real treat, you can stretch out, move your chair to whatever position you like. The Four Seasons Centre is a gem, outstanding acoustics and visually stunning. Last year we skipped the National Ballet Nutcracker live and instead saw the Bolshoi version at the movie theatre. We thought that version was very bland and tired. The National Ballet version is fun, colourful and just warms your heart. Even if you never thought you'd like a ballet, who cannot resist dancing mice, bears and even a horse. Such a delight to see so many children attending, exposed to such an excellent cultural experience. Kudos to the National Ballet for the acknowledgement of being on First Nations lands. A wonderful Christmas experience for any family, instead of purchasing material gifts that may be forgotten in a few months. Just a wonderful afternoon.

reviews.title: Incredible! Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland
text: This ballet was so incredible for many reasons. The dancing last night (Thursday to see cast online) was top notch, as to be expected from this company. What was so mesmerizing were the addition elements that brought everything to life including the magnificent costumes, stages and live orchestra. We couldn’t stop talking about the various dancers and their characters all the way home. If you can still get tickets, go see this ballet!

reviews.title: Another mesmerizing  performance!
text: We attended another fabulous performance at this beautiful venue. We saw 'Apollo'. WOW. A really astounding experience to enjoy. The precision in these dances was astounding. Gorgeous costumes, excellent music by highly trained musicians. Wonderful to see so many different age groups at this event as well. Everyone was having a great time. Highly recommended for anyone; you don't have to be a 'classical' dance lover to enjoy this experience. Truly special. The only negative comment we would include was the VERY expensive cost of wine/prosecco. Too much!

reviews.title: Did a dance lesson here- adored it!
text: If you fancy taking up a ballet experience elsewhere (from beginner to advanced level) it is definitely worth going to see. I could have only wished there was merchandise to buy- I'd have bought a t-shirt!

reviews.title: Beautiful Sleeping Beauty
text: I saw Sleeping Beauty, it was very good, excellent costumes, beautiful sets and fabulous principal dancers, the others were not quite in sync but good.

reviews.title: Alice's Adventure in Wonderland
text: Amazing show! I'm always so blown away by the talent at the ballet. The costumes and sets were great, the score was very well suited to the show, and the dancing was brilliant. The seating is also quite good, I think most of the seats at Four Seasons have a good view, including the standing room tickets (standing tickets can be bought for $12 on the day of the performance, and you get a railing in front of you to lean on + each spot has a hook for coats). I haven't bought any of the partially obstructed view tickets yet so I'm no sure about those, but the rest have all been great.

reviews.title: National Ballet of Canada Alice in Wonderland
text: This was such an awesome experience! My wife and I received free tickets to 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland' Dress Rehearsal ballet. I've never been to a ballet before so I definitely wanted the experience! I wasn't sure what to expect. I have been through part of the facility before because it is linked to the Osgoode subway station which is a very convenient way to get there as well as it being extremely handicapped accessible for all sizes of scooters and wheelchairs. It seems to be a very large building with high ceilings and lots of open space. Everything feels like a work of art from the art that is on display to the glass walls, open concept stairs, piano, to the main auditorium with exquisite wood work on the chairs, walls, floors, and banisters. I didn't know if the ballet was like a play where the actors spoke so it was interesting when I realized they were just going to dance and you had to figure out the story from their body language and the awesome, awesome, awesome orchestra. I was very happy to see they left the orchestra pit open during the whole performance so I could watch the musicians as well as the athletes performing. I thought this would be an excellent way for a group such as Circque du Soleil to perform as well.The story was mostly familiar with some surprises along the way. I've seen various movies of Alice in Wonderland but don't remember some of the adventures portrayed here. I've included pictures below. Really the only issue I had was options of food and drinks. A little pricey and could have been healthier choices. I would have liked popcorn actually. lol

reviews.title: A Christmas Tradition...the Nutcracker
text: I love the National Ballet of Canada's performance of the Nutcracker!  Always magical, and always takes me back to my visit to Russia.  I have been waiting years to take my granddaughter, and this was the year....six years old and she said that the WHOLE performance was her favourite, she loved the costumes and that the night was magical.  She is right!

reviews.title: another Christmas tradition
text: This ia a tradition for many families around this time of year.  The production is always stunning and the music is wonderfully comforting and familiar.  Kathy P. mentions that there isn't a bad seat in the house, and she is absolutely right.  The best part of the production is watching the children who attend as they become mesmerized with the dance, and are soon twirling, in their seats and in the aisles.  There are few better introductions to dance and music for children of all ages. It is magical.

reviews.title: Stunning as always!
text: Beautifully done! We sat in the grand ring and had a breathtaking few! Lots of families with children at the matinee performance. Some of the other ballet-goers were pretty snotty and rude though. Cute little gift shop, but expensive. Typical T.O prices for cocktails.

reviews.title: Excellent "Nutcracker" Production!
text: Great production, talented casty, superb staging and props. Don't miss this excellent production of a timeless classic!

reviews.title: The Nutcracker is Always a Winner!
text: My daughter and I saw this ballet on December 23, 2014 at 5:30 p.m.  We were seated in the Grand Ring.  The seats were excellent.  We have seen the performance many times before, and it never gets stale.  The orchestra was superb.  The dancing was great, with Sonia Rodrigues dancing as the Sugar Plum Fairy.  She is so elegant and precise….I was mesmerized.  The stage props were wonderful, with the rat crossing the stage and the prancing horse!  It is a wonderful production for all ages.  We also have to say that we loved the mini Coke bottles that one could purchase as a refreshment, and the Rose Reisman catering assorted mini-sandwiches….very tasty.  After the performance, we bought a Nutcracker and a Nutcracker Christmas ornament.  We went out for dinner afterwards.  It was a real treat for all.  Will we return?  Absolutely!  It was an enchanted evening, and a wonderful way to celebrate the festive season.

reviews.title: The best way to spend an evening
text: I have been a patron of the National Ballet for many years and love it. The performances are top-notch and the costumes and dancers are exquisite. I love the Four Seasons as a venue from the pre-show and intermission bar service to the comfortable seats. Not a bad seat in the house. Very enjoyable I encourage people to take advantage of this fine dance company.

reviews.title: Nutcracker! Magnificient.
text: My daughter and I enjoyed our first national ballet together. The Nutcracker is simply spectacular. WOW

reviews.title: ``and everthing is beautiful at the ballet ...
text: I`ve loved ballet since I took some lessons as a child and the National Bellet of Canada never disappoints afficianados of this mode of dance. When I travel to Toronto I always check to see if there is a performance at The Four Seasons for the Performing Arts Centre. If you love ballet, check them out when you`re next in town - you won`t regret it!

reviews.title: Enchanting!
text: Several of us went to see their performance of the Nutcracker. It was absolutely magical, and our seats were quite comfortable. The only downside is the cost.. it can be quite prohibitive.

reviews.title: Romeo and Juliette
text: Went to see a performance of the above ballet last night and loved everything about it.  The venue is stunning and the performance was wonderful.  The costumes, the dancing and the beautiful music - outstanding.  Especially  loved one movement by the ladies of the court where they appeared to be going across the stage on wheels!  They were actually dancing across the stage on points, moving extremely fast.  Brilliant.

Only one thing spoilt our enjoyment.  A very young child, maybe 5 or 6, was sitting in front of us with her mother.  Romeo and Juliette is not an especially good choice for one so young and she was so bored.  The child didn't sit still for more than a few minutes; up down, up down playing with her seat, playing with her hair, waving her arms in the air and loudly whispering to her mother.  Please parents, be more considerate of other patrons around you.

reviews.title: Beautiful building but cramped, inaccessible seating detract from the experience
text: The building is grand and impressive as befits its title. We saw the Nutcracker. Pretty good show but cramped, inaccessible seating detract from the experience. My nut was cracked by the end of it.

reviews.title: Some feedback
text: I am glad I saw the Nutcracker as it is a Christmas classic.  I knew it was ballet and I wouldn't love it, however some constructive criticism for you:
1. Staff were very snobby and not good with customer service.  For example, Usher dropped my program didn't say one word or offer to pick it up for me.
2. Very pricey
3. Not very high level of ballet.  Timing was off and dancers were not precise.  The first couple of numbers dancers were basically hopping around.  I could do that.

4. Needs some updating.  Maybe more flips or Ariel.  Something more exciting.  Lots of long drawn out repetitive hops around stage.  And animal abuse.  Caging rats and trying to kill a chicken.  Very out dated.
5. Orchestra was wonderful
6. Audience clapping all over the map.  No clear cut finishes.
7. Good luck fitting in the seating if you are tall.  Do not see the play if you are scared of heights.

reviews.title: Disappointed...no place for political correctness in art.
text: The set was wonderful.  The dancers gave their best.  The costumes were superb.

So why disappointed?  It seems the Political Correctness Police have taken over the artistic direction of the National Ballet.  One of the most enjoyable dances is the Oriental Dance which was excised I presume lest it offend anyone of Asian extract.

Does this mean that next year the Arabian Dance is out?  Tchaikovsky must be rolling in his grave.  You should have left social engineering and politics out of it and stuck to what you know...dance.  Artistic direction has lost its way and does not deserve this important responsibility.  Time for a change.

reviews.title: Outstanding classical ballet
text: I saw "Romeo and Juliet" choreographed by Ratmansky.

I enjoyed the ballet talk by Lindsey Fischer 45 minutes before the performance. He spoke about details of the representation of this classic tale by Ratmansky. He provided valuable insights to the performance.
The ballet was moving. The performers well expressed the emotions of the dramatic scenes. What a moving tale!
The artists readily executed challenging moves. This is a company of gifted performers.

reviews.title: Even if it is a once in a lifetime thing, give it a try.
text: The Nutcracker. This is an annual treat for me that my darling A arranges.  This was opening night and there was a change in the line up with a replacement for the principal male.  I hope the original is OK, he had a nasty fall on stage on opening night last year.  His understudy did well... not quite as well but pretty good.

But this is the Nutcracker after all, who could not be enchanted?  We would so love to see more of the ballets through the year but live quite a way from Toronto so for now at least, an annual event at Christmas/Festive Holiday Period.

Even if you are not into ballet then have a look at the building.  It is very beautiful.  The architecture and design is crisp and clean, the seating comfortable and well done.  They may wish to reconsider people standing at the back, talking, chewing, even singing, and leaning over the poor people in the seats immediately in front of them.
The bar, don't bother, it is over-priced for sub-standard wine.  The gift shop, sorry folks but I'd say the same.
Be warned, the elevator has a mind of its own.  Apparently it will 'do the floors' in a strict order so there is no point pushing the button, which begs the question 'Why have a button?'
Leaving and trying to get a taxi is a nightmare.  Better to just hold off for about 10 minutes until the rush is over and then walk down and around the corner, you have more chance that way.

Even if you only go there once in a life time, consider it.  Ignoring the bad wine and elevator problems and the fact that they don't have enough seating while you are waiting to get in to the performance, the ballet and architecture/design make for that.... almost.

reviews.title: Romeo and Juliet
text: Extraordinary performance
The National Ballet just gets better and better. Great score for a great orchestra
The dancing by the other soloists are wonderful
This is truly a Ballet Company
Can't wait to see the Nutcracker again
I never know how they manage to survive with the quality and expenses it must take

reviews.title: Family Tradition, Still Going Strong
text: I have been attending this with my daughter over the last 4 years. We love it. The music, the performance, the theatre - everything is magical. We stood in line this year to get signatures at intermission from two of the dancers; they were fantastic.

reviews.title: This is NOT a professional performance
text: It was interesting to see a reviewer mention the same thing 5-years earlier.

Purchased a significant amount of tickets to what I thought was going be a wonderful performance. On the contrary - it was horrible, and sloppy at best. I did not find out until the following day that most of the performers were students. Sorry, but are you kidding me.

If you want to see a truly professional performance of the Nutcracker than go to the Sony Centre For The Performing Arts which features stars of the Bolshoi Ballet. However, if you want to see students practicing then go to the National Ballet of Canada.

reviews.title: Excellent performance
text: I was amazed by the performance. The ballerinas are professional and the choreography is fantastic. The building itself is also very nice especially in the evening.

reviews.title: Sleeping Beauty is magnificent!
text: Saw this ballet recently and it was simply wonderful.  Costuming was brilliant and the performance was exquisite.  The Four Seasons Centre is a first-rate venue for the ballet and did not disappoint in any way.
Tickets for this ballet are expensive but worth the cost - especially if this is a treat!

reviews.title: Billed as "The Nutcracker", this Pageant is stunning in its own right- but no Nutcracker.
text: The set design and the costumes were eye-popping beautiful.  The ballet is a series of well-choreographed ensemble dances.  There were many festive special effects that worked, such as a dancing bear on roller skates and an amazing horse on stage (was it real or costume?).  Just do not look for the magical Christmas coming-of-age story of Clara; her nutcracker prince engages with a pas de deux with another woman and the whole production fizzles out with a farcical food fight.

reviews.title: Nijinsky - Exquisite Experience!!
text: Went to an evening performance - so glad I could get tickets! Much appreciated the Ballet Talk by Peter Ottmann, the Senior Ballet Master, at 6:45 - well worth attending. He explained the ballet as ‘representation’ of a particular moment in Nijinsky’s life: his last performance. Founded upon details derived from extensive research, particularly iconic gestural motifs captured in photographs, the ballet touches upon significant moments and performances in the life of this world renowned star. John Neumeier’s selected score is beautiful and presented by the National Ballet Orchestra (Chopin, Schumann, Shostakovich). On from November 22-26, 2017. With matinee and evening Performances. Tickets online and at the Box Office.

Convenient access from the Four Seasons Performing Arts Centre subway access at Osgoode (Queen Street) station so you don’t have to brave the cold! Convenient preorder of intermission refreshments saves time at the 20 minute intermission. Bars at all levels. Coat check on lower level.

reviews.title: Magnificent Performing Arts Center
text: Exquisite architecture and display. The whole experience was worth it. Superb performance. A must go place to enjoy the culture and history of the dancing arts.

reviews.title: Pinnochio ---Dance 3-Looks 10
text: I was looking forward to seeing this ballet and though visually gorgeous and with some very effective music, the choreography was a real let down.It felt very "50's TV" dancing. Insubstantial with lots of mediocre leaping about and running around that we've all seen a thousand times before. This work certainly did not strain the technical virtuosities of Canada's great ballet company. It felt quite long and there are repetitive and tedious passages that would benefit muchly from elimination. Disappointing.

reviews.title: A must-do activity in Toronto
text: Went to see the Nutcracker, a beautiful performance, the orchestra was magnificent, I enjoyed the entire performance.  A great evening, a must-do activity in Toronto, no matter which ballet you see.

reviews.title: A wonderful afternoon at the ballet
text: Though many may feel that ballet and opera are elitist and of no interest, how can you argue with an art form that has survived for a hundred or two hundred years? The National Ballet of Canada is a national treasure and something that everyone should experience at least once. And the most accessible and fun ballet has to be the Nutcracker, for all ages. Saw the New Year's Eve and final 2016 performance and what a wonderful afternoon. Just spectacular dancing and top notch music from the orchestra. A visual treat and a complete escape from real life. The Four Seasons Centre adds to the experience, felt almost pampered, what a great venue.
